content: P.L. 106-554, signed in December 2000, enacted the Treasury, Postal Service, Executive Office of the President, and General Government Appropriations, 2001. It provided funding for various accounts, including the General Services Administration for transition administration and the Executive Residence for White House family transfers. P.L. 106-346 (H.R. 4475) partially funded select accounts from the primary funding measure. Various measures were considered before enacting P.L. 106-554 for FY2001 appropriations. The key details provided include House bill H.R. 4871, Senate bill S. 2900, Legislative Branch Appropriation H.R. 4516/H.R. 4985, Transportation Appropriations P.L. 106-346 (H.R. 4475), FY2001 Continuing Funding Resolution P.L. 106-275, and The Act P.L. 106-554 (H.R. 5658). The President submits the Budget of the United States Government annually to Congress. The United States Government submitted the budget for FY2001 on February 7, 2000. Congress establishes a procedure to pass a concurrent resolution setting budgetary levels for future years. The House and Senate Appropriations Committees allocate discretionary funding levels to subcommittees, including Treasury and General Government appropriations. This funding covers various law enforcement organizations under the Department of the Treasury, such as the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, and Firearms, Customs Service, Secret Service, and others. The U.S. Postal Service is mostly self-supporting, with limited federal contributions to the Postal Service Fund. Federal contributions are limited to payments to the Postal Service Fund to compensate for revenues foregone, such as free postal service for the blind. Appropriations for the Executive Office of the President provide salaries and expenses for various agencies within the EOP, including the Council of Economic Advisers and the National Security Council. Funding for drug control initiatives is distributed by the ONDCP to other entities. Independent agencies funded through this appropriation include the Federal Election Commission, the General Services Administration, and the National Archives and Records Administration. The Treasury and General Government appropriation includes restrictions that apply governmentwide. The curr_chunk discusses standard language in government appropriations that apply restrictions and authorize defined actions, such as prohibiting the use of funds for non-U.S. citizens, maintaining drug-free workplaces, and paying travel expenses for federal employees' immediate family members. It also mentions a .22% across-the-board rescission of FY2001 discretionary budget authority and obligation limitations funds. The Office of Management and Budget is required to report on the implementation of the rescission in the FY2002 budget. The Office of Management Budget issued guidelines for the implementation of a .22% across-the-board rescission of FY2001 discretionary budget authority and obligation limitations. The rescission applies to all net positive discretionary budget authority and obligation limitations, including advance appropriations for FY 2001 provided in FY 2000 or earlier years. Discretionary emergency appropriations are also subject to the rescission, with a requirement for a 0.22% reduction to be applied equally to each program, project, and activity. Each program, project, and activity must be reduced by 0.22% without discretion to change the allocation. The rescission of 0.22% must be applied to discretionary PPA, with reductions made on a pro-rata basis to every program, project, and activity. Agencies will receive their specific rescission amounts from OMB. The FY2000 Consolidated Appropriations Act mandated a 0.38% across-the-board rescission, with OMB reporting specific reductions in accounts. Each department had flexibility to protect high-priority programs while achieving the required savings. The FY2001 rescission provisions exempt certain programs, but are universally applied otherwise. The FY2000 Supplemental funding provisions are included in the FY2001 Military Construction Appropriations Act. The pay date for federal civilian personnel will revert to the original scheduled date in FY2000, altering the funding levels. The FY2000 enacted funding levels and legislative measures for FY2001 Treasury and General Government appropriations are summarized in the table. Various bills were passed or debated in Congress, including H.R. 4871, S. 2900, H.R. 4985, P.L. 106-346, and P.L. 106-554. Hearings and markup sessions were held by the House Committee on Appropriations Subcommittee on Treasury, Postal Service, and General Government. The Subcommittee markup for H.R. 4871 was on July 11, with the full Appropriations Committee reporting the bill on July 18. The House passed H.R. 4871 on July 20 by a vote of 216-202. The Senate Committee on Appropriations Subcommittee on Treasury, Postal Service, and General Government held hearings in February, March, and April, sending the bill to the full committee on July 19. Cloture was invoked on July 26 with a vote of 97-0, and debate on H.R. 4871 was pending before the Senate adjourned on July 27. On July 26, 2000, H.R. 4985 was introduced by Jim Kolbe for Treasury Department appropriations. The House agreed to the rule for the Legislative Branch FY2001 appropriations bill on July 27. On September 14, 2000, the House approved the conference report for H.R. 4516, but the Senate rejected it on September 20. The Senate rejected the conference report on October 20 by a vote of 28 to 69. On October 12, the Senate agreed to the conference report by a vote of 58 to 37. The bill was vetoed by the President on October 30. The House recommitted the bill and veto message to the House Committee on Appropriations on October 31. Funding for FY2001 accounts was mostly at FY2000 levels through continuing resolutions. New accounts had no funding from October 1 to December 21, 2000, except for the General Services Administration account for the presidential transition. The White House was authorized to use funds for transition preparations through continuing resolutions. The Transportation FY2001appropriation, H.R. 4475, reached agreement on October 5, with the conference committee filing a report. Both the House and Senate agreed to the conference language on October 6. P.L. 106-346 was signed by the President on October 23, 2000. P.L. 106-554 enacts H.R. 5658, the Treasury and General Government Appropriations, FY 2001, through reference. H.R. 5658 was introduced as a new bill with funding levels identical to H.R. 4985. Customs' Automated Commercial System (ACS) has been inadequate in recent years. Authorization in substantive law allows for appropriations for programs or agencies. Direct spending is budget authority provided in laws other than annual appropriations acts, classified as mandatory spending. It is subject to PAGO rules and includes appropriated entitlements. Discretionary spending, on the other hand, is budget authority provided in annual appropriations acts excluding appropriated entitlements. Federal funds encompass all government monies except trust funds. Obligations are binding agreements requiring payment, while outlays are payments made to fulfill obligations. The Budget Enforcement Act established PAGO to prevent deficit increases or surplus reductions from revenue and direct spending legislation. Revolving Funds use income for operations without fiscal year limits. Scorekeeping tracks budgetary actions, and Supplemental Appropriations provide additional budget authority.
